businessModels.name: Subscription
businessModels.description: Customers pay a recurring fee for continuous access to a product or service.
businessModels.context:
Description: Customers pay a recurring fee for continuous access to a product or service.
Historical Example: Netflix transformed media consumption by offering unlimited streaming content for a monthly fee, replacing traditional rental and purchase models.
MENA Example: SubsBase emerged as the region's first subscription management platform, raising $2.4 million in seed funding to help regional businesses implement subscription models.

businessModels.name: Freemium
businessModels.description: Basic features are offered free while premium features require payment, serving as a customer acquisition strategy.
businessModels.context:
Description: Basic features are offered free while premium features require payment, serving as a customer acquisition strategy.
Historical Example: Dropbox attracted users with free cloud storage, monetizing through paid upgrades for additional space and features.
MENA Example: Anghami, the region's leading music streaming platform, uses freemium pricing with ad-supported free tier and premium subscriptions.

businessModels.name: Marketplace
businessModels.description: A platform connecting buyers and sellers, generating revenue through commissions or fees without holding inventory.
businessModels.context:
Description: A platform connecting buyers and sellers, generating revenue through commissions or fees without holding inventory.
Historical Example: eBay connected buyers and sellers globally, creating a vast online marketplace for goods.
MENA Example: Noon.com operates as a leading marketplace in the UAE, Saudi Arabia, and Egypt, connecting regional retailers with consumers.

businessModels.name: Razor and Blades
businessModels.description: Selling a core product at a low price or loss (razors), then generating profits through recurring sales of complementary consumables (blades).
businessModels.context:
Description: A strategy where companies sell a core product at a low price or loss (razors), then generate profits through recurring sales of complementary consumables (blades).
Historical Example: HP sells printers at low margins but makes significant profits on ink cartridges.
Popular Example: Nespresso sells its coffee machines at cost while generating significant profits through the recurring sales of proprietary coffee pods.

businessModels.name: Crowdsourcing
businessModels.description: Leverages collective intelligence by obtaining ideas, services, or content from a large group through online platforms.
businessModels.context:
Description: Leverages collective intelligence by obtaining ideas, services, or content from a large group through online platforms.
Historical Example: Wikipedia built a vast encyclopedia through user-contributed content.
MENA Example: Beehive, based in Dubai, uses crowdsourcing for peer-to-peer lending, connecting SMEs with investors.

businessModels.name: Pay-Per-Use
businessModels.description: Customers only pay for their actual usage of a product or service, with ownership and maintenance remaining with the provider.
businessModels.context:
Description: Customers only pay for their actual usage of a product or service, with ownership and maintenance remaining with the provider.
Historical Example: Utilities charge customers based on the amount of electricity or water consumed.
MENA Example: CAFU, UAE's fuel delivery service, charges customers only for the amount of fuel delivered, without subscription fees.

businessModels.name: Peer-to-Peer
businessModels.description: A platform connecting individuals directly to exchange goods or services, with the business acting as an intermediary.
businessModels.context:
Description: A platform connecting individuals directly to exchange goods or services, with the business acting as an intermediary.
Historical Example: BitTorrent enabled decentralized file sharing among users without a central server.
MENA Example: Liwwa, a Jordan-based P2P lending platform connecting SMEs with investors for business financing.

businessModels.name: On-Demand
businessModels.description: Services or products delivered instantly when requested through digital platforms, focusing on immediate fulfillment.
businessModels.context:
Description: Services or products delivered instantly when requested through digital platforms, focusing on immediate fulfillment.
Historical Example: Uber provides transportation services on demand via a mobile app.
MENA Example: Talabat, providing immediate food delivery services across multiple MENA countries.

businessModels.name: Aggregation
businessModels.description: Combines multiple service providers under a single brand, standardizing offerings and customer experience.
businessModels.context:
Description: Combines multiple service providers under a single brand, standardizing offerings and customer experience.
Historical Example: Kayak aggregates flight information from various airlines, allowing users to compare and book travel options.
MENA Example: Careem Super App, aggregating rides, food delivery, and payments under one platform.

businessModels.name: Open-Source
businessModels.description: Software code is freely available, with revenue generated through support, hosting, or premium features.
businessModels.context:
Description: Software code is freely available, with revenue generated through support, hosting, or premium features.
Historical Example: Linux, an open-source operating system, thrived through community collaboration and contributions.
Alternative Example: Bagisto, an open-source e-commerce platform with built-in support for MENA markets.

businessModels.name: Licensing
businessModels.description: Companies grant rights to intellectual property, trademarks, or technology in exchange for fees or royalties.
businessModels.context:
Description: Companies grant rights to intellectual property, trademarks, or technology in exchange for fees or royalties.
Historical Example: Microsoft licenses its software to users and businesses, generating revenue from widespread adoption.
MENA Example: Emirates Airlines licenses its brand for hospitality and entertainment ventures across the region.

businessModels.name: Data Monetization
businessModels.description: Leveraging user data to generate revenue through targeted advertising or insights.
businessModels.context:
Description: Leveraging user data to generate revenue through targeted advertising or insights.
Historical Example: Facebook offers free services but monetizes user data through targeted advertising.
MENA Example: Souq.com (now Amazon.ae) utilizing customer data for personalized shopping experiences.

businessModels.name: Platform
businessModels.description: Creates value by facilitating exchanges between two or more interdependent groups.
businessModels.context:
Description: Creates value by facilitating exchanges between two or more interdependent groups.
Historical Example: Apple's App Store allows developers to create apps for its ecosystem, generating revenue for both parties.
MENA Example: EMPG (Bayut/Dubizzle), connecting property sellers, buyers, and agents across MENA.

businessModels.name: Network Effects
businessModels.description: The value of a product or service increases as more users join the network.
businessModels.context:
Description: The value of a product or service increases as more users join the network.
Historical Example: Facebook's value increases as more users join, enhancing connectivity and engagement.
MENA Example: Property Finder, a MENA real estate platform that connects property seekers, sellers, agents, and mortgage providers.

businessModels.name: Sharing Economy
businessModels.description: Platforms enabling users to share underutilized assets or services.
businessModels.context:
Description: Platforms enabling users to share underutilized assets or services.
Historical Example: Airbnb allows property owners to share their homes with travelers, monetizing unused resources.
MENA Example: ekar, a car-sharing platform in UAE and Saudi Arabia, enabling vehicle sharing among users.

businessModels.name: Vertical Integration
businessModels.description: Controlling multiple stages of production and distribution across the value chain.
businessModels.context:
Description: Controlling multiple stages of production and distribution across the value chain.
Historical Example: Tesla controls everything from car manufacturing to battery production and software updates.
MENA Example: Aramex's end-to-end logistics solutions, controlling the entire delivery chain.

businessModels.name: Bundling
businessModels.description: Combining multiple products or services into a single package offering.
businessModels.context:
Description: Combining multiple products or services into a single package offering.
Historical Example: Microsoft Office bundles Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, providing value through a suite of products.
MENA Example: etisalat by e&'s bundled packages combining mobile, internet, and TV services.

businessModels.name: White Label
businessModels.description: Products or services produced by one company but rebranded and sold by others.
businessModels.context:
Description: Products or services produced by one company but rebranded and sold by others.
Historical Example: Generic products are rebranded and sold by different retailers under their own brand names.
MENA Example: PayTabs, providing white-label payment solutions to businesses across MENA.

businessModels.name: Franchising
businessModels.description: Business expansion through licensing brand name, processes, and operational methods to independent operators.
businessModels.context:
Description: Business expansion through licensing brand name, processes, and operational methods to independent operators.
Historical Example: McDonald's expands globally by allowing franchisees to operate under its brand with standardized processes.
MENA Example: Al Baik, Saudi Arabia's popular fast-food chain, expands across GCC through strategic franchising partnerships.

businessModels.name: Advertising
businessModels.description: Offering free or subsidized services while generating revenue through advertising space and targeted marketing.
businessModels.context:
Description: Offering free or subsidized services while generating revenue through advertising space and targeted marketing.
Historical Example: Google provides free search services funded by targeted advertising based on user data.
MENA Example: Shahid VIP combines free ad-supported content with premium subscriptions across the Arab world.
